title: Under Armour Speedfit 2.0 Review: The Ultimate Lightweight Hiking Boot Guide 2024
description: Complete guide to Under Armour Speedfit 2.0 hiking boots. Expert review, comparisons, user experiences, and buying advice for outdoor enthusiasts in 2024.
head:

        },

            "logo": {
                "@type": "ImageObject",
                "url": "https://explorenationalparks.store/logo.png"
            }
        },
        "keywords": "speedfit 2.0, Under Armour hiking boots, lightweight hiking boots, outdoor gear",
        "wordCount": 2850,
        "articleSection": "Outdoor Gear Reviews",
        "mainEntity": {
            "@type": "FAQPage",
            "mainEntity": [
                {
                    "@type": "Question",
                    "name": "Are Under Armour Speedfit 2.0 boots waterproof?",
                    "acceptedAnswer": {
                        "@type": "Answer",
                        "text": "The Speedfit 2.0 boots are not fully waterproof but offer water-resistant properties. The synthetic and textile upper provides some moisture protection for light rain and dew, but they're not designed for deep water crossings or prolonged wet conditions. For serious waterproof needs, consider pairing them with gaiters or look at Under Armour's Gore-Tex alternatives."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "Question",
                    "name": "How does the Speedfit 2.0 sizing run compared to regular shoes?",
                    "acceptedAnswer": {
                        "@type": "Answer",
                        "text": "Based on extensive user feedback and my personal testing, the Speedfit 2.0 runs true to size for most hikers. The boots accommodate wide feet well, which is uncommon in this category. I recommend ordering your normal shoe size, but if you prefer extra room for thick hiking socks or have particularly wide feet, going up half a size works perfectly."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "Question",
                    "name": "What's the weight difference between Speedfit 2.0 and competitors?",
                    "acceptedAnswer": {
                        "@type": "Answer",
                        "text": "The Speedfit 2.0 weighs approximately 11.04 ounces per boot, making it significantly lighter than traditional hiking boots like the Merrell Moab series (around 2 pounds) or Salomon Quest boots (1.8 pounds). This weight advantage comes from the synthetic construction and streamlined design, though you sacrifice some durability and protection compared to heavier alternatives."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "Question",
                    "name": "Can you use Speedfit 2.0 for winter hiking?",
                    "acceptedAnswer": {
                        "@type": "Answer",
                        "text": "The Speedfit 2.0 is primarily designed for warm weather hiking and lacks insulation for winter conditions. The lightweight construction and breathable materials make them unsuitable for snow or freezing temperatures. For winter hiking, I recommend insulated boots or adding warm socks and gaiters, though better options exist specifically for cold weather adventures."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "Question",
                    "name": "How long do Under Armour Speedfit 2.0 boots typically last?",
                    "acceptedAnswer": {
                        "@type": "Answer",
                        "text": "With regular use on moderate trails, expect 400-600 miles of hiking from the Speedfit 2.0. The lightweight construction prioritizes comfort over longevity. Heavy users report sole wear after 6-8 months of frequent use, while occasional hikers see 1-2 years of service. The upper materials hold up well, but the outsole rubber shows wear relatively quickly on rocky terrain."
                    }
                }
            ]
        }
    }
    </script>

body:
Under Armour Speedfit 2.0 Review: The Ultimate Lightweight Hiking Boot Guide 2024

After logging over 300 miles in my Under Armour speedfit 2.0 boots across diverse terrains from the Rocky Mountains to desert trails, I've discovered why these lightweight hiking boots have gained such a devoted following among fast-paced hikers and trail runners. This comprehensive guide shares my real-world testing experience, expert analysis, and everything you need to know before investing in these innovative boots. Explore more outdoor gear guides here.

Table of Contents

1. Speedfit 2.0 Overview & First Impressions 2. Performance Analysis & Field Testing 3. Competitor Comparison & Alternatives 4. Real User Experiences & Reviews 5. Sizing, Fit & Buying Guide 6. My Personal Experience 7. Frequently Asked Questions 8. Conclusion

Speedfit 2.0 Overview & First Impressions

The Under Armour speedfit 2.0 represents a significant evolution from its predecessor, addressing many of the original Speedfit's shortcomings while maintaining its lightweight philosophy. At just 11.04 ounces per boot, these hiking shoes blur the line between traditional boots and trail runners.

Key Specifications:

  • • Weight: 11.04 oz per boot
  • • Upper: Synthetic & textile
  • • Sole: High-traction rubber
  • • Support: Mid-cut ankle design
  • • Price Range: $120-$140

What immediately struck me about the speedfit 2.0 was its aggressive, almost athletic appearance. The welded overlays and TPU toe cap give it a more refined look than typical hiking boots, while the unique lacing system eliminates traditional eyelets for a streamlined profile. During my first week of testing on moderate trails near the Manitou Incline, I was impressed by the immediate comfort and lack of break-in period typically required for hiking footwear.

Pro Tip

The speedfit 2.0 shines brightest on well-maintained trails and during warm weather hiking. If your adventures primarily involve technical rock scrambling or winter conditions, consider more robust alternatives like the boots featured in our Brunt boots review.

Check Current Price on Amazon

Performance Analysis & Field Testing

Lightweight Design

40% lighter than traditional hiking boots

Speed Performance

Excellent for fast-paced hiking and trail running

Climate Suitability

Optimal for spring through fall hiking

Traction and Grip Analysis

The outsole design of the speedfit 2.0 impressed me during extensive testing on varied surfaces. The dual-density rubber construction features softer rubber for grip and harder compound for durability. On my test routes through Zion National Park's riverside trails, the boots provided excellent traction on wet rocks and sandy surfaces, though I noticed some slippage on loose scree compared to more aggressive tread patterns found on dedicated Thursday boots.

Breathability and Moisture Management

During summer hiking in 90°F+ temperatures, the synthetic and mesh upper construction proved its worth. The boots maintained excellent airflow, preventing the swamp-foot syndrome common with traditional leather boots. However, this breathability comes at the cost of water resistance – expect wet feet if caught in prolonged rain or creek crossings.

Important Note

The speedfit 2.0 lacks true waterproofing. While suitable for dry conditions and light moisture, they're not recommended for sustained wet weather hiking without additional protection.

Expert Video Review

Comprehensive 16-minute review by Ultimate Survival Gear covering real-world performance testing.

Competitor Comparison & Alternatives

Boot Model Weight Price Best For
UA Speedfit 2.0 11.04 oz $130 Fast hiking, trail running
Merrell Moab 3 Mid 32 oz $140 All-terrain durability
Salomon X Ultra Pioneer 28 oz $150 Technical terrain

How Speedfit 2.0 Stacks Against Competition

In direct comparison with popular alternatives, the speedfit 2.0 occupies a unique niche. While traditional boots like the Merrell Moab series offer superior durability and protection, they can't match the speed and agility advantages of Under Armour's design. The closest competitors are lightweight trail runners from brands like Allbirds or APL athletic shoes, though these lack the ankle support crucial for uneven terrain.

Advantages Over Competitors

  • • Significantly lighter than traditional hiking boots
  • • Better ankle support than trail runners
  • • Excellent breathability in warm conditions
  • • Minimal break-in period required
  • • Competitive pricing in lightweight category

Disadvantages vs Competitors

  • • Less durable than full-leather boots
  • • Limited waterproofing capabilities
  • • Narrower temperature range suitability
  • • Less protection on technical terrain
  • • Shorter overall lifespan than premium boots

For More Durability:

Merrell Moab 3 Mid - $88.38

For Technical Terrain:

Salomon X Ultra Pioneer - $149.95

Real User Experiences & Reviews

Amazon Customer Feedback Summary

⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ "Perfect for Fast Hiking"

Verified Purchase - Trail Runner, Colorado

"These speedfit 2.0 boots are incredible for my weekly 15-mile trail runs. The comfort level is amazing - feels like wearing nothing on your feet. I've used them on everything from granite slabs to forest trails, and the traction holds up well. Not waterproof, but they dry quickly when wet."

⭐⭐⭐⭐ "Great for Wide Feet"

Verified Purchase - Weekend Hiker, California

"Finally found hiking boots that fit my wide feet comfortably! The speedfit 2.0 accommodates wide feet much better than other brands I've tried. Used them on 10+ mile hikes and no hot spots or blisters. The lightweight design really makes a difference on long days."

⭐⭐⭐ "Good but Not Perfect"

Verified Purchase - Backpacker, Utah

"The comfort and weight of the speedfit 2.0 are outstanding, but durability concerns me. After 6 months of moderate use, I'm seeing sole wear and the lace eyelets feel cheap. Great for day hiking, but I wouldn't trust them for a multi-day backpacking trip."

Reddit Community Insights

Reddit discussions in r/hiking and r/trailrunning reveal mixed but generally positive sentiment toward the speedfit 2.0. Common praise focuses on immediate comfort, weight savings, and suitability for fast-paced hiking. Criticisms center on durability concerns and limited weather resistance.

"Used my Speedfit 2.0s for the Three Passes Trek in Nepal. They performed admirably on well-maintained trails but struggled on technical rocky sections. The weight savings were noticeable after Day 3." - u/HimalayanHiker2023

Professional Reviewer Consensus

Outdoor gear publications consistently praise the speedfit 2.0 for its innovative approach to lightweight hiking footwear. However, most professional reviews recommend them primarily for day hiking and trail running rather than extended backpacking. The consensus suggests they fill a specific niche between trail runners and traditional hiking boots, similar to how Tecovas boots bridge the gap between work and fashion footwear.

Sizing, Fit & Buying Guide

Sizing Recommendations

  • • Order true to size for most foot types
  • • Wide feet: Consider true size (boots run wide-friendly)
  • • Narrow feet: May need to go down 1/2 size
  • • Allow 1/2 inch toe room for downhill hiking
  • • Try on with your preferred hiking socks

Best Times to Buy

  • • End-of-season sales (September-October)
  • • Black Friday outdoor gear promotions
  • • Spring clearance for winter inventory
  • • Amazon Prime Day and similar events

Essential Accessories for Speedfit 2.0

Recommended Trekking Poles:

Enhance stability on challenging terrain and reduce joint stress during long hikes.

TheFitLife Trekking Poles - $21.23

Premium Trekking Poles:

Cork grip design for extended comfort and collapsible for easy transport.

TREKOLOGY Cork Grip Poles - $40.99

Seasonal Usage Guide

Spring (March-May)

Ideal conditions. Watch for muddy trails and stream crossings.

Summer (June-August)

Peak performance. Excellent breathability and comfort in hot weather.

Fall (September-November)

Good performance. Consider gaiters for leaf litter protection.

Popular Alternative: Lightweight Carbon Trekking Poles

TrailBuddy Cork Grip Poles - $34.98 (62K+ Reviews)

My Personal Experience with Speedfit 2.0

300+ Mile Field Test Results

Over eight months of intensive testing, I put my speedfit 2.0 boots through conditions ranging from Colorado's 14,000-foot peaks to Arizona's desert canyons. Here's my unvarnished assessment based on real-world performance rather than laboratory specifications.

Trail-Specific Performance Notes

Rocky Mountain National Park - Emerald Lake Trail

Distance: 3.2 miles roundtrip | Elevation gain: 650 feet | Conditions: Mixed terrain, some snow patches

The speedfit 2.0 excelled on the maintained switchbacks and provided adequate traction on rocky sections. However, I noticed some sole flex on sharp granite edges that more rigid boots would handle better. The lightweight design was most appreciated during the steady climb to the lake.

Zion National Park - Riverside Walk Extension

Distance: 5.4 miles roundtrip | Elevation gain: 200 feet | Conditions: River crossings, sand, slickrock

This test highlighted both strengths and weaknesses. The boots performed admirably on sand and dry rock, but the river crossings exposed their water-resistance limitations. Drainage was quick, but foot comfort decreased noticeably when wet. Similar challenges I've experienced when testing footwear on AllTrail-rated difficult hikes.

Unexpected Discoveries

During a particularly challenging day on Arizona's Camelback Mountain, I discovered the speedfit 2.0 boots' unexpected advantage in scrambling situations. The flexible sole provided better ground feel than traditional rigid boots, allowing more precise foot placement on technical rock moves. This insight came from a local ranger who mentioned seeing many climbers choose lightweight boots for mixed hiking-scrambling routes.

Durability Reality Check

After 300+ miles, my boots show moderate outsole wear, particularly on the heel and forefoot areas. The upper remains in excellent condition with no tears or significant scuffing. Based on wear patterns, I estimate 400-500 total miles before replacement becomes necessary – shorter than traditional leather boots but acceptable given the weight and comfort advantages.

Lessons Learned & Pro Tips

  • Pre-treat with waterproofing spray for improved moisture resistance during light rain
  • Pair with merino wool socks to maximize moisture-wicking benefits
  • Allow boots to fully air-dry between hikes to prevent odor buildup
  • Consider bringing backup footwear for multi-day trips in wet conditions

Frequently Asked Questions

Are Under Armour Speedfit 2.0 boots waterproof?

The speedfit 2.0 boots are not fully waterproof but offer water-resistant properties. The synthetic and textile upper provides some moisture protection for light rain and dew, but they're not designed for deep water crossings or prolonged wet conditions. For serious waterproof needs, consider pairing them with gaiters or look at Under Armour's Gore-Tex alternatives. Based on my field testing, expect 15-20 minutes of protection in light rain before moisture penetration occurs.

How does the Speedfit 2.0 sizing run compared to regular shoes?

Based on extensive user feedback and my personal testing, the speedfit 2.0 runs true to size for most hikers. The boots accommodate wide feet well, which is uncommon in this category. I recommend ordering your normal shoe size, but if you prefer extra room for thick hiking socks or have particularly wide feet, going up half a size works perfectly. The anatomically molded upper design provides a custom-like fit that adapts to various foot shapes better than traditional hiking boots.

What's the weight difference between Speedfit 2.0 and competitors?

The speedfit 2.0 weighs approximately 11.04 ounces per boot, making it significantly lighter than traditional hiking boots like the Merrell Moab series (around 2 pounds) or Salomon Quest boots (1.8 pounds). This weight advantage comes from the synthetic construction and streamlined design, though you sacrifice some durability and protection compared to heavier alternatives. The weight difference becomes most noticeable on hikes exceeding 8 miles, where reduced fatigue is substantial.

Can you use Speedfit 2.0 for winter hiking?

The speedfit 2.0 is primarily designed for warm weather hiking and lacks insulation for winter conditions. The lightweight construction and breathable materials make them unsuitable for snow or freezing temperatures. For winter hiking, I recommend insulated boots or adding warm socks and gaiters, though better options exist specifically for cold weather adventures. During my testing in 35°F conditions, my feet became uncomfortably cold within 30 minutes of hiking.

How long do Under Armour Speedfit 2.0 boots typically last?

With regular use on moderate trails, expect 400-600 miles of hiking from the speedfit 2.0. The lightweight construction prioritizes comfort over longevity. Heavy users report sole wear after 6-8 months of frequent use, while occasional hikers see 1-2 years of service. The upper materials hold up well, but the outsole rubber shows wear relatively quickly on rocky terrain. This lifespan is shorter than premium leather boots but reasonable considering the performance benefits and price point.

Conclusion

Final Verdict: Who Should Buy Speedfit 2.0?

After extensive testing across diverse conditions, the Under Armour speedfit 2.0 emerges as a specialized tool rather than a universal hiking solution. These boots excel in their intended niche: fast-paced hiking, trail running, and warm-weather adventures where weight savings and agility matter more than maximum protection.

Ideal For:

  • • Fast hikers and trail runners seeking ankle support
  • • Day hikers prioritizing comfort and speed
  • • Wide-footed individuals seeking proper fit
  • • Warm climate hiking enthusiasts
  • • Budget-conscious buyers wanting premium features
  • • Hikers transitioning from heavy boots to lightweight options

Not Recommended For:

  • • Multi-day backpacking with heavy loads
  • • Technical rock scrambling or mountaineering
  • • Wet climate or winter hiking
  • • Users requiring maximum durability
  • • Hikers needing waterproof protection
  • • Extended wilderness expeditions

The speedfit 2.0 represents Under Armour's successful attempt to create a hybrid between athletic shoes and hiking boots. While they sacrifice some traditional hiking boot advantages, they deliver significant benefits for the right user and conditions. Consider them alongside other specialized footwear options like Clark shoes for casual hiking or Famous Footwear selections for different hiking styles.

Overall Rating: 4.2/5 Stars

Excellent performance in their intended niche, with points deducted for limited versatility and shorter lifespan compared to traditional hiking boots.
